fields.title: David W. Hill Diaries
fields.desc:
Diaries of David W. Hill, Brass Finisher, of Cambridgeport, Mass., NYC, and Haydenville, Mass., dating from 1864-1885. About 180 pages each, 3 days per page format. 7x3", mostly limp black leather covers with loop & tab. _x000d_
_x000d_
Extensive record of daily work ('Worked polishing in the fore noon finished the job of 237 No-O oil cups, began on 28 large ones in the after noon.'), personal details of travel, visits, plus weather.

fields.title: Cynthia Shepherd Letter
fields.desc:
Letter from Cynthia Shepherd (?), Dartmouth (Mass.?) dated Nov. 31 (?), 1717. _x000d_
_x000d_
"dear Brother and Sister I Set down in love to wright to you how we dew we are all well only of with my side is very lame and stomach very sore but of desire to be thankfull to think I am hear with my Litel Children the Lord had bin mercifull to me and I hope these Lines will find you in a good state of helth and pray to the Lord that he may strenkin you and me to work out our one Selves Selvation with fear and trembling . . . I want to see you and talk about these heavenly things o how my love is inlarged but I cant tell youmy dear brother and sister but I will leave you in the hands of a Coind and maceyfull father so no more at present but i remain your loving sister cynthia Shepherd."_x000d_
_x000d_
Other side reads 'Somerset' with few other words, including "cat good dog good"._x000d_
_x000d_
Creased, worn, fair. 13x8", watermarked paper.

fields.title: West Springfield Airport, Inc. Records
fields.desc:
West Springfield Airport, Inc. records (1946-1955) in two binders._x000d_
_x000d_
Volume 1 contains: Charter, Articles of Agreement, By-Laws (17 p.), Index (7 p.), Minutes of Stockholders' Meetings (73 p.), Stock Register & Mailing List (3 p.)._x000d_
_x000d_
Volume 2 contains: Minutes of Executive Meeting (6 p.), Minutes of Directors Meetings (ca. 167 p.), April 5, 1946 - August 5, 1954, covering incorporation, issue of stock, acquisition of real estate, disposal of real estate, liquidation & settlement of finances.

fields.title: The Pines (South Hadley Falls, Mass.) Register
fields.desc:
The Pines (South Hadley Falls, Mass.) register/log from 1925-1939. Entries in hotel register blank book. Many signatures of guests at Coon Suppers, Deer Dinner, Game Supper, Turtle Soup Dinner, Chicken Fry, Piano Supper, Pig Roast, Turkey Supper, Mystery Supper, also guests at Farewell Party for Chuck Hoffman, Wedding of Bob & Helen, 'First official visitation of 'Pines Gang' to 'Bosch Club' at 'Lake Congamond', 'Our Gang' a lengthy poem treating many members, 'Log' for several years - narrative of club activities, fishing & hunting, music & drama, maintenance of buildings & grounds, some personal events._x000d_
_x000d_
14x8.5", half red leather, black cloth boards, gold lettering. 112 p.

fields.title: Ebenezer C. Baily Papers
fields.desc:
Business papers of Ebenezer C. Bailey of Boston, dating from 1852-1882. Includes manuscript documents on printed letterhead, invoices for slippers & shoes from nearby wholesale suppliers & manufacturers, receipts for payments from commercial customers, some from the midwest, plus a few pieces of personal & financial correspondence, few tax receipts. _x000d_
_x000d_
Relative to wholesale buying & selling of slippers, discussing quality of merchandise & delivery, fate of payments.

fields.title: Deerfield Valley Lodge, No. 150 Records
fields.desc: Deerfield Valley Lodge, No 150, Ancient Order of United Workmen (Selburne Falls, Mass.) records dating from 1895-1920. Conists of applications, bonds, roll calls, receipts, transfers, reports, correspondence.

fields.title: North Center School District Records
fields.desc:
Records of the North Center School District (Hatfield, Mass.) dating from 1818-1833. Consists of warrants for meetings to make appointments of instructors & committees, consider finances & building, accounts for school expenses, site for schoolhouse. _x000d_
_x000d_
Documents in various hands, many names of selectment & committee members, instructors.

fields.title: Perry Green Comstock Ledger
fields.desc:
Ledger of Perry Green Comstock of Housatonic, Great Barrington, and West Stockbridge, Mass., dating from 1862-1880. Comstock (1808-1892), built woolen mill in West Stockbridge in 1840, rebuilt as paper mill after fire. General account book with primarily entries for goods, labor, rents, cash, check, board, jobs, daybook page & amount, but also including entries for calender rolls, paper, wrap, weaving yards, sacks, dyestuff, lumber. There are accounts with Monument Mills, M.S. Hovey & Co, Troy, Smith Paper Co, Berkshire Woolen Co, Owen Paper Co, Kniffin & Brother. _x000d_
_x000d_
197 p. of account in 336 p. lined blank book. Laid in: 1 sheet for castings, turning rolls & repairing equipment, 1 sheet for pulp, 2 manuscript account sheets, 1873 & 1876, printed & manuscript invoice with envelope from Andrew Geyer's Wood Pulp & Fiber Mill Directory, NY, 1893. Note on endsheet: 'Property Insured on Paper Mill 1872. Mill Building 3000, Machinery 10000, Stock 1800'. _x000d_
_x000d_
13x8" blind-tooled suede, black leather spine labels with gold tooling, 197 pages of accounts in 336pp lined blank book.

fields.title: Stephen Siteman Collection on American Socialism
fields.desc: The Siteman Collection contains Siteman's correspondence with Frank P. Zeidler, 1984-1991 (0.25 lin. ft.), materials relating to the Democratic Socialist Conference, 1985-1989 (0.25 lin. ft.), and numerous books and pamphlets on American Socialism, including especially works by Norman Thomas.  The manuscript portion includes a number of photographs, and a group of framed documents, photographs, and newsclippings have been separated for storage.  The material was acquired in 1991, but apparently not accessioned.

fields.title: Louise Shattuck Spiritualist Collection
fields.desc: Diaries, automatic writing, transcripts of ouija board sessions, letters, drawings, memorabilia, and photos relating to Louise Shattuck (d. 2005) of Lake Pleasant.  Included are two spirit slates relating to her mother or possibly grandmother, a chromo print (darkened and damaged) in frame of Lake Pleasant, ca.1885-1890, and much more.  Louise was a Spiritualist from a Spiritualist family, a breeder of English cocker spaniels, and artist.

fields.title: Ross, Laura. Papers
fields.desc: Long a member of the Communist Party USA and leader in the Massachusetts branch, Laura Ross (b. 1913) is remembered for twice running as the only opponent for Tip O'Neill's 8th Congressional District seat.  In 1984, Ross received 15,668 votes, almost 8% of the total.  She was one of the founders of the Center for Marxist Education on Central Square in Cambridge.

fields.title: Katanka-Fraser Political Music Collection
fields.desc: Politically-themed sheet music, records, etc., from US, UK, Germany, and Russia and elsewhere. The collection is named for the two men who assembled it: James Fraser, former library director at Farleigh-Dickinson University, and Michael Katanka (ca.1924-1985), an English labor historian and antiquarian book expert.  Includes materials relating to the British and American workers' movements, labor, Socialism and Communism, the Spanish Civil War, Red Army, Vietnam, and Cuba.

fields.title: Tom Deary Papers
fields.desc: Tom Deary was a union organizer, for the IUE, affiliated with Local 201 at the Lynn GE plant.  He was on the executive board of the local, was a shopfloor steward.  Involved in the 1969-1970 strike, Deary joined the IUE staff in 1971 and served for 30 years as an organizer, negotiator, and strike leader in the northeast and southern states.  Frequently at odds with union careerists, he built a small newspaper in the 1980s into a regional labor newspaper, New England Labor News and Commentary.  The collection includes organizer reports, correspondence, IUE election campaign literature, and oral histories and videotapes.

fields.title: Henry Gustave Reinsch Collection
fields.desc: 65pp. pages of documents and scrapbook relating to 1943 disloyalty charges brought against Reisch.  A German-born naturalized US citizen, Reisch was an anti-Semite associated with William Dudley Pelley’s fascist Silver Shirt Legion (akin to the larger German American Bund).  The collection includes six letters from Reisch to his wife, correspondence with his attorney, and legal motions, etc.

fields.title: Robert and Waldemar Schultze Papers
fields.desc: ca.120 letters from the Schultzes written while interned during the Second World War as pacifists.  The Schultzes were possibly Jehovah’s Witnesses, were definitely non-compliant, and for a period were incarcerated at Fort Leavenworth.

fields.title: Women Against Garage (WAG) Records
fields.desc:
Informally referring to themselves as WAGs (Women Against Garage), Fay Kaynor, Mary Snyder, Merrylees Turner, and Mary Wentworth, opposed the building of a parking garage in the center of Amherst. Together they collected newspaper clippings, reports, minutes of meetings, and flyers that tell both sides of the story, but in particular shed light on the motivations of those opposed to the garage, concerns not well represented in the local paper, the Amherst Bulletin, at the time. _x000d_
_x000d_
Potential problems raised by garage opponents focused on the environmental issues that added traffic in Amherst would introduce, as well as the financial impact both on the town, if the revenues from the garage did not cover the investment or maintenance costs, and on locally-owned businesses that might not be able to afford higher rents if property values near the garage increased significantly.

fields.title: Greg Antipa scanning electron micrographs
fields.desc: Micrographs of ciliates, etc.  From his website at SFSU: Research interests: cell biology, ciliate development, electron microscopy.  My laboratory concentrates on basic problems which can be best approached with the use of protozoa as either model systems or pragmatic solutions to fundamental problems in biology. They center around: 1) issues of general ecology, 2) cellular development, and 3) structure/function relationships. With respect to the latter, inasmuch as the protozoa are both cells and organisms, the emphasis has been on just what cellular adaptations have been made to accomplish life as a unicellular eukaryote. In the case of development, my laboratory has paid special attention to the role of basal bodies and centrioles in their regulation & semiautonomy during growth and cellular division. Insofar as ecology is concerned, the program of division is applied to the estimate of the growth of these organisms, the behavior of ciliated protozoa as they respond to chemical environmental cues, and finally an evaluation of the role protozoa play in the decomposition of organic wastes, particularly during the activated sludge process. The activities of my laboratory have been funded by grants from the National Science Foundation (NSF), the National Institutes of Health (NIH), the Department of Energy (DOE), and the Office of Water Resource Research (OWRR).

fields.title: Nash family photo albums, pamphlets; Herman B. Nash scrapbook; covered bridge scrapbook
fields.desc:
Scrapbooks and photo albums_x000d_
_x000d_
Album of trip to West Coast, 1915.  315 photos, 26x34 cm.  All identified._x000d_
Including images of Portland, Ore., Yellowstone, San Francisco World's Fair, Los Angeles and Pasadena, San Diego Fair, Yosemite, California missions Grand Canyon, Hopi and "Apache" adobe houses._x000d_
_x000d_
Album of canoe trip to Labrador, 1920.  265 photos, 26x32 cm.  All identified._x000d_
Including images of St. Lawrence River, Montreal, slums of Sous le Cap (excellent images), Quebec City, Ste Anne de Beaupre, "Half breed spinning," "Indian squaw, San Prin," Labrador, Maine coast_x000d_
_x000d_
Covered Bridge scrapbook, 1907-1970_x000d_
Extensive scrapbook containing newsclippings, notes, photographs (18), postcards (30), and real photo postcards (12) of covered bridges in New England.  All laid in with corner mounts and nearly all pristine._x000d_
_x000d_
Herman B. Nash Mass. Agricultural College and World War I scrapbook._x000d_
Truly extensive scrapbook of Herman Nash, graduate of Smith's Agricultural High School, Northampton, and MAC (1917).  Includes ca.125 photos of front lines in France (purchased over there), ca. 75 candid photos taken by Nash during the war, and ephemera such as identification cards, arm patch, company rosters, German propaganda leaflet picked up near the front, programs, tickets, etc., relating to his service.  MAC materials include dance cards, tickets, baseball programs, and miscellaneous ephemera relating to the College.  _x000d_
_x000d_
_x000d_
_x000d_
Pamphlets_x000d_
_x000d_

[The angel's book]. Whatley, Mass.: Joshua Belden, 1820, Spectacular narrative of vision: "I was a great Angel, that had two eyes that could see a thousand miles apart…"  Apparently unrecorded_x000d_
The Chemist and Meteorological Journal, v.1, no.8.  Amherst: John R. Cotting, 1826. Scarce early scientific periodical; ran only vol. 1, no.1-20_x000d_

Ballou, Hosea, A sermon delivered at the Universalist meeting, in Boston…. Boston: Henry Bowen, 1818.  Fair only.  Signature of Israel Scott_x000d_
Chalmers, Thomas, The efficacy of prayer: A sermon preached at St. George's Church, Edinburgh… being the day appointed for a national fast on account of the prevalence of cholera, 3d ed. S.l.: s.n., 1832.  Scarce sermon on cholera pandemic_x000d_
Channing, William Ellery, A sermon preached at the annual election, May 26, 1830… Boston: Carter and Hendree, 1830_x000d_

Hubbell, Seth, A narrative of the sufferings of Seth Hubbell and family in his beginning a settlement in the town of Wolcott, in the state of Vermont. Danville, Vt.: E. & W. Eaton, 1827.  First printed 1824, but scarce in any printing_x000d_
Hutton, Joseph, Omniscience the attribute of the father only. Boston: Bowles and Dearborn, 1827_x000d_
Lewis, Hannah, Narrative of the captivity and sufferings of Mrs. Harriot Lewis and her three children, who were taken prisoners by the Indians… Boston: George Billings, 1818.  Exceptional captivity narrative from St. Louis area in original paper wraps with hand-colored frontis.  First printed 1817_x000d_
Lyman, Joseph, The Guilt and danger of religious error: A sermon preached at Hatfield, before the ministers of the Central Association… Northampton:: Thomas W. Shepard, 1821.  Fair condition only_x000d_
Massachusetts. Constitutional Convention, Report upon the Constitutional rights and privileges of Harvard College… Boston: Russell and Gardner, 1821.  Ownership signature of Israel Scott_x000d_

fields.title: Peter Duus Papers
fields.desc:
Peter Duus, William H. Bonsall Professor of History and Fellow by courtesy at Stanford's Hoover Institution, received his doctorate from Harvard in modern Japanese history and taught at Harvard, Washington University and the Claremont Graduate School before coming to Stanford to teach Japanese and East Asian history in 1973.  Since the early 1960s Professor Duus has spent more than 10 years, off and on, living in Japan. _x000d_
_x000d_
Professor Duus' accomplishments and accolades include:_x000d_
_x000d_
    * Past president of the Association for Asian Studies_x000d_
    * Member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences_x000d_
    * Research fellowships from the Ford Foundation, the National Endowment for the Humanities, the Japan Foundation and the Fulbright Commission_x000d_
    * Taught at the International Division of Waseda University in Tokyo and twice served as the resident professor at the Stanford Center for Japanese Studies in Kyoto_x000d_
    * Author of two widely used textbooks on Japanese history, Feudalism in Japan and The Rise of Modern Japan_x000d_
_x000d_
Research Interests_x000d_
_x000d_
    * Japanese imperialism and colonialism_x000d_
    * Development of Tokyo_x000d_
    * Modern political cartoon_x000d_
_x000d_
Courses Taught_x000d_
_x000d_
    * Pearl Harbor_x000d_
    * The United States and East Asia, 1840-present_x000d_
    * Nineteenth Century Japan_x000d_
    * The Rise of Modern Japan_x000d_
    * Postwar Japan_x000d_
    * Japanese Lives - Autobiography and History_x000d_
    * Nationalism and Imperialism in Modern Japan_x000d_
    * Meiji Culture_x000d_
    * Imperialism, Colonialism, and National Identity in Modern Japan_x000d_
    * Graduate Colloquium: Modern Japan_x000d_
_x000d_
Publications_x000d_
_x000d_
    * The Japanese Discovery of America: A Brief History with Documents, 1997._x000d_
    * Modern Japan, 1997._x000d_
    * Co-Editor, The Japanese Wartime Empire, 1996._x000d_
    * The Abacus and the Sword: The Japanese Penetration of Korea, 1895-1910, 1995._x000d_
    * Feudalism in Japan, Third Edition, 1992._x000d_
    * Co-Editor, Japan's Informal Empire in China, 1989._x000d_
    * Editor, The Cambridge History of Japan, vol. 6. The Twentieth Century, 1989._x000d_
_x000d_
Awards_x000d_
_x000d_
    * Berkeley Prize, 1996-1997_x000d_
    * Hiromi Arisawa Prize, 1996_x000d_
    * Akira Iriye International Book Award, 1996_x000d_
    * Fulbright Research Fellowship, 1994-95_x000d_
    * Japan Foundation Research Fellowship, 1986-87_x000d_
_x000d_
University Service_x000d_
_x000d_
    * Former Director, Center for East Asian Studies_x000d_
_x000d_
Professional Affiliations_x000d_
_x000d_
    * American Academy of Arts and Sciences_x000d_
    * American Historical Association_x000d_
    * Association for Asian Studies, Vice President_x000d_
    * Senior Fellow (by courtesy), Hoover Institution

fields.title: Irene A. Chapin Diaries
fields.desc: Four diaries of Irene Chapin, Chicopee and La Crescenta, Calif., reputedly lesbian.  From dealer: "They were written in the years 1926, '27, '28 and '35 by a lesbian woman living in La Crescenta, California through 1927 but moves to Chicopee Massachusetts by 1928... She has a beautiful, legible handwriting and offers an interesting study of a lesbian lifestyle in pre World War II California. The first three diaries are very 'newsy' and jam-packed with her everyday activities at home and at work, giving insight into her relationship with Marion, her partner. She opens each page with a note stating the weather of the day, and proceeds to list her activities, interactions and overall feelings. What is interesting is that on some pages in the diary, she has chosen to use shorthand at the bottom of the entry. The later diary finds her changed 7 years later. She continues to open up each and every entry with the weather, but she lacks vim as in the first few. She seems to have aged more than the seven actual years that have passed."  Also from dealer: "I called the person I bought these from - a regular source of diaries for me - and she repeated to me that these came from a estate of a lesbian woman and it came through her purchase from marion's estate. Marion moved to california it appears later in life she said."

fields.title: Local 925, Tufts University Records
fields.desc:
In October 1978 a group of clerical workers at Tufts united in an effort to organize their coworkers with Local 925, S.E.I.U. Isolated and scattered across campus, the clerical employees at the university greeted this call to unionize with support, hoping it would mean an improvement in salaries and in grievance procedures. By the summer of the following year, 60% of eligible employees signed authorization cards, more than required to vote on the issue, and an election early that fall was expected. Tufts administration, however, delayed the election by disputing the composition of the bargaining unit. Formal hearings took place from September through the end of the year, but instead of resolving the case, the Boston Labor Board referred it to Washington on January 25, 1980. Nine months later the election was finally held, but the results were not what were anticipated more than a year earlier. Rather than an easy victory to unionize, the majority of clerical staff at Tufts voted not to make Local 925 their exclusive bargaining representative. The administration’s anti-union campaign waged throughout 1979 and 1980 had a tremendous impact on the employees at the university, and a number of concessions made on wages, health insurance, and vacations further eroded support for organizing with Local 925._x000d_
_x000d_
The collection documents the efforts of Tufts clerical workers to unionize during 1978-1980. The group’s biweekly newsletter, Inside Tufts, written by the university’s employees and published by Local 925, offers an important behind-the-scenes look on two fronts: the issues and grievances of the clerical staff at Tufts and the reasons behind their decision to unionize. Materials relating to the efforts of other Boston-area institutions, in particular colleges and universities, are also included.

fields.title: Wind turbine schematics (UMass Wind Turbine WF-1)
fields.desc: Schematics for Wind Furnace 1 (WF-1), the first modern wind turbine in the US built by William Heronemus and colleagues at UMass in mid-1970s.  At the time it was the largest wind turbine in the US and possibly the world.  The turbine was decommissioned and dismantled in 2004, and sent to the Smithsonian in 2009.

fields.title: Work on Waste Records
fields.desc: From St. Lawrence U site: Dr. Paul Connett, a chemistry professor at St. Lawrence University and his wife Ellen, formed Work on Waste with the help of other citizen environmentalists. Though the mid 80s and into 1990, WOW questioned the county's Solid Waste Authority, its consultants, the State and county lawmakers about every aspect of the incinerator project; its safety, economic viability and its effect on other ways of dealing with the waste stream, principally recycling. With WOW leading the charge, much public discontentment over the incinerator/landfill plan was generated, putting significant political pressure on the 22 member County Legislature.  Following a contentious election season in the fall of 1989, the legislature voted in July of 1990 to not approve the bonding for the incinerator. The vote was 11-11, but with a weighted voting system in place, the anti-incineration forces were victorious.

fields.title: W.H. Grindol & Son Marble Works letterbook
Benjamin Hoag Records (oologist)
fields.desc:
The archive consists of 1,345 letters (1,610 pages), mainly incoming letters written by customers of Benjamin Hoag, and is business related. Of the 1,345 letters, only 18 are written by Hoag. Most are hand written, with some typed and signed. Almost all of the letters have envelopes. The letters are posted from all over the United States, with several from Canada. While the archive extends from 1901 to 1915, it mainly consists of correspondence between the years 1907 to 1914._x000d_
_x000d_
In addition there are some minor miscellaneous paper ephemera, such as bank deposit slips, receipts, etc.  The archive contains the following material: 1,345 letters, 1,610 pages, as follows:_x000d_
_x000d_
Letters of 1901: 1letter, 1 page_x000d_
_x000d_
Letters of 1906: 10 letters, 14 pages (1 letter by Hoag)_x000d_
_x000d_
Letters of 1907: 328 letters, 392 pages (2 letters by Hoag)_x000d_
_x000d_
Letters of 1908: 220 letters, 269 pages (7 letters by Hoag)_x000d_
_x000d_
Letters of 1909: 181 letters, 218 pages (4 letters by Hoag)_x000d_
_x000d_
Letters of 1910: 175 letters, 204 pages (3 letters by Hoag)_x000d_
_x000d_
Letters of 1911: 118 letters, 157 pages (1 letter by Hoag)_x000d_
_x000d_
Letters of 1912: 116 letters, 140 pages_x000d_
_x000d_
Letters of 1913: 92 letters, 104 pages_x000d_
_x000d_
Letters of 1914: 95 letters, 102 pages_x000d_
_x000d_
Letters of 1915: 9 letters, 9 pages_x000d_
_x000d_
431 Miscellaneous Paper Ephemera Items:_x000d_
_x000d_
389 Manuscript Bank Deposit Receipts of Benjamin Hoag for deposits made at the Agricultural National Bank of Pittsfield, Massachusetts, giving amounts of deposits and from what city or town the money originated, all dated 1911 to 1915 as follows: 13 slips, dated 1911; 88 slips, dated 1912; 102 slips dated 1913; 124 slips dated 1914; 29 slips, dated 1915;  21 slips, with day and month, no year; 12 blank slips; 53 envelopes, separated from their letters_x000d_
_x000d_
35 Letterhead Receipts for items sold to Benjamin Hoag, dated 1909-1914_x000d_
_x000d_
5 letters, 5 pages, not dated, written to Benjamin Hoag_x000d_
_x000d_
1 letter, 1 page, not dated, not addressed to anyone, signed "Gertrude"_x000d_
_x000d_
1 letter, 1 page, written by Benjamin Hoag, not dated_x000d_
_x000d_
 Biography of Benjamin Hoag_x000d_
_x000d_
Benjamin Hoag was born at Ancram, New York March 14, 1865. He spent most of his life living at Stephentown, New York, about 25 miles east of Albany near the Massachusetts border. Hoag married Gertrude Atwater, (b.10 Nov 1877- d.1972), on 27 Oct 1899. She was the daughter of William Henry Atwater (1849-1920) & Ella Blanche Haynes. The couple had no children._x000d_
_x000d_
The Census of 1900 shows Benjamin boarding with his wife's family. Gertrude's father was a miller in Stephentown. In 1900, Hoag was listed as a dealer in bicycles. By 1910, the couple was living on their own, in a home they purchased in Stephentown and Hoag was listed as a retail merchant in dry goods & grains. The 1920 Census shows that the Hoag's had two nieces living with them. The 1930 Census shows Hoag listed as a merchant owning a grocery store. In 1930, he is living with his wife Gertrude._x000d_
_x000d_
Benjamin Hoag died two years after the 1930 Census was taken, on September 9, 1932. His obituary stated that he was a "well known merchant." Gertrude Hoag died on April 28, 1972 at the age of 97, outliving her husband by forty years. Her obituary stated that she operated a general store in Garfield, New York for more then 30 years. She was buried with her husband at Garfield Cemetery._x000d_
_x000d_
While the census records and Hoag's obituary state that he was a merchant, he was no ordinary merchant. He also was the proprietor of an ornithological and oological business, handling books and periodicals, with ornithological, scientific and natural history works being a specialty. Besides the printed material, Hoag also bought and sold instruments for naturalists, oologists and taxidermists, as well as oological specimens. The correspondence in the collection also shows him to have run a magazine subscription agency offering everything from the Saturday Evening Post and Good Housekeeping to the Condor Magazine._x000d_
_x000d_
The correspondence is mainly incoming letters from customers of Hoag's Oology and magazine subscription businesses. There are occasional letters of Hoag, where customers wrote back to Hoag on the same letter that Hoag sent them. Almost all letters have the original envelopes, with many bearing letterhead of taxidermists, ornithologists, as well as other businesses. There is also some miscellaneous paper ephemera related to Hoag's business, things like letterhead receipts and bank deposit slips for the Agricultural National Bank of Pittsfield, Massachusetts. The bank deposit slips are interesting as there are almost 400 of them over a short time period (1911-1915). The combination of the incoming letters, mostly orders or inquiries, with the bank deposit slips, gives a very good insight into the accounts of this unique early 20th Century oological business and magazine subscription agency that flourished during the heyday of bird egg collecting. The hobby was outlawed by 1918.

fields.title: The Life and Travels of Abel Turner, Minister of the Gospel
fields.desc:
Manuscript autobiography of Abel Turner, (1811-1866), a Free Will Baptist Minister, from Foxcroft, Maine, covering his life from 1811 until the year 1839. Included in the biography are accounts of his conversion to the Free Will Baptist doctrine, as well as his travels in Maine, Vermont and to Western New York State._x000d_
_x000d_
The reverse side of the title page states:_x000d_
_x000d_
"When I commenced writing I had not the least idea of any one ever seeing it except my Mother or some near friends. Since I were married I often resolved to burn what I had written but for the sake of my wife have consented to write it over for her, and if any compitent [sic] judges should think it worth publishing for the F. W. Baptist it may be, after my dicease [sic]. Freedom 28 Dec. 1839 - A. Turner."_x000d_
_x000d_
We have been unable to determine that any writings by Abel Turner, including either the present manuscript, sermons or other theological writings were ever published. (OCLC: 0)_x000d_
_x000d_
The Rev. Abel Turner was the son of Adam Turner (b. 1743) and Daphny Bradman (b. 1741-d. 1811). Turner's autobiography states that his father was born at Pembroke, Massachusetts, and descended from John Turner, who came over with the Pilgrims. Of Turner's eight siblings, only Betsey and our writer, Abel Turner, came to Foxcroft, Maine, from their original hometown of Hebron, Maine. Foxcroft is today's Dover-Foxcroft, about 35 miles northwest of Bangor._x000d_
_x000d_
In 1814, Abel Turner's father is supposed to have come to Foxcroft with his family to a small log cabin on lot #16 in the 4th range. Foxcroft had only been settled in 1806, thus the Turners were early pioneers in this then sparsely populated area of Maine. Soon after their arrival to Foxcroft, Turner's third son Adam B. Turner was born and late in 1818 his fourth daughter Betty B. Turner was born.        _x000d_
_x000d_
Abel Turner, was a very bright young man and is said to have been ordained in the ministry at the age of twenty-one years, or about they year 1832.  The first 29 pages of the present manuscript are not dated, with Turner only starting to date his autobiography on March 14th, 1832, when he was 21 years old and beginning his ministry. The early years of his ministry were spent preaching in the area of Piscataquis and Penobscot Counties, in Maine. He spent time in the Moosehead Lake region in the west central area of the state, traveling from settlement to settlement trying to "convert sinners" and in some cases forced to travel on old logging roads, as there were no roads to get to the settlements.  _x000d_
_x000d_
Turner notes early in the manuscript the following description of an Indian settlement in Maine:_x000d_
_x000d_
"As we passed up the river we saw a few log huts where resided a few poor Indians, the aborigines of our country. Poor Indian! We passed their burying grounds where they had just buried on of their numbers. As I passed this place I could but reflect upon the unhappy condition. They had got to leave their lands and ashes of their fathers in about three years! O unhappy race! How mournfully must these poor people leave the hills and vales, streams and woods of their nativity. How will the memory of these scenes linger upon their thoughts as they take the last look of there pleasant homes to journey to the far West."_x000d_
_x000d_
 Turner states that early in life (at age 4-5) he had become interested in the hereafter and was visited by dreams of life after death. Raised a rigid Calvinist, Turner soon began exploring Universalism after hearing a preacher. When he was about 18 years old (c1819) the hold that Universalism had on him began slipping. In Turner's own words we find that:_x000d_
_x000d_
"When I was about eighteen there was an extensive revival of religion in Guilford and many with whom I had formerly been acquainted turned to the Lord."_x000d_
_x000d_
Turner soon began attending the Baptist revival meetings and in short time decided he would not be a Calvinist nor Universalist, but a Free Will Baptists. At about page 30 of the present journal Turner is 21 years old and the rest of the work deals with period of his conversion, ministry until aged 28._x000d_
_x000d_
At one point Turner travels from Bangor, Maine to New York where he visits his brother:_x000d_
_x000d_
"My brother has been sick with the colory during its ravages in that city in 1831. While confined to his room he said he counted thirty coffins carried by his house to the silent home of the dead! Such were the ravages of death in that city."_x000d_
_x000d_
After spending a week in New York Turner heads to Dearfield, New York, near Utica, where he thought a Free Will Baptist Church was located. He traveled to Albany by the steamboat DeWit Clinton, then by railroad to "Schenectada," and from there "by the Canell [sic] to Utica." He further describes his trip by cana_x000d_
_x000d_
"The most of the way was rather unpleasant especially on the canell [sic]. This is the wickedest place that I ever saw; especially for swearing. There is nothing so strange in this since there is some thousand groceris [sic] and taverns on this canell [sic]! If parents want their boys to learn all manner of wickedness let them send them on the canell [sic]!_x000d_
_x000d_
Upon arriving in Utica, Turner mentions:_x000d_
_x000d_
"We arrived in Utica a few days after the Anti Slavery Convention had been broken up by a mob. It appears that some in the city were opposed to there meeting in the place; and excited the Irishmen who were to work on the railroads just above there to come to their aid; with clubs, stones, brickbats, etc. and thus hundreds of the best men in the State were pisically [sic] driven from the city; for the crime of meeting to discuss and adopt the best means of liberarting millions of American Sitisans [sic] from the worst state of slavery. !! O Liberty how art thou fallen! Spirit of Seventy six Where hast thou flu! lord save our country from the scourge that we have so justly merited."_x000d_
_x000d_
Turner after discovering that the Free Will Baptist Church that he thought was near Utica was not in existence, he then went on to Rochester and Parma, New York, by canal. Turner spent the winter and spring of 1835-36 in this area of Monroe and Orleans Counties, preaching to "the sinners and backsliders", as well as attending conferences, before heading back to New York City for a final visit with his brother before heading back to Maine. While in New York he writes a rather harsh criticism of the place:_x000d_
_x000d_
"Of this city I can say if any man has the ordinary feelings of humanity his heart will be touched. Here are the most distressing scenes of poverty, misery and profanity! Thousands crowding their way to ruin through the chanels [sic] of intemperance [sic] and debauchery!_x000d_
_x000d_
After returning to Foxcroft and preaching in that area for a while, Turner in the fall of 1837 takes his family and heads west. He goes back to Western New York, to various towns in Genesee, Orleans, and Monroe Counties, places he had been previously. He spends several months in this area of New York State, and in mid December takes an appointment at Poultney, Vermont, but the leading men in the church decide they could not support him, not giving a reason. With his belongings still back at Byron, New York, Turner did not know where next to turn and finally takes an appointment with the Yates Q. M. Home Mission Society, (presumably Yates County, NY) and travels in the Q.M. until the May term, after which he decides to go to Southern Ohio. He travels and preaches at various towns along the way, but the manuscript ends before he leaves New York State._x000d_
_x000d_
The last fifty pages of the manuscript are a separate chapter dealing with his appointment at the Freedom and Farmersville Church, presumably in Cattaraugus County, New York. On Page 139, Turner states:_x000d_
_x000d_
"For great clearness I have kept the account of the reformation in the Freedom and Farmersville church separate from my other appointments until now. The following is designed for to give a more particular account."_x000d_
_x000d_
After this statement, the last fifty pages deal with his appointment to this church._x000d_
_x000d_
Turner lived out the rest of his life in Maine as a Free Will Baptist preacher in Chester, Penobscot County, Maine.

fields.title: Diary of a Western Tour, Massachusetts and Connecticut.  12mo, 55 pages stitched together, without wrappers, rear leaf chipped at edges, dated August 8, 1825-August 16, 1825.
fields.desc:
55p. Diary of a nine day carriage trip of what the writer terms a "western tour" through Connecticut and Massachusetts, starting at Mt. Pleasant, Massachusetts, to Litchfield, Connecticut and then returning by way of Springfield, Northampton and Belchertown, Massachusetts. There are stops at Stevens, and Brimfield, Massachusetts, then Stafford, Tolland, Vernon, Hartford and Litchfield in Connecticut._x000d_
_x000d_
While the identity of the diarist is unclear there is a note on the rear leaf that states: "Grandfather Clapp took grandmother and her father and mother on this trip Grandfather and grandmother were engaged. They were married the next year."_x000d_
_x000d_
The party consisting of a Mr. Clapp, a "Mrs. D." and a Lucia, plus the diarist, sets out from Mt. Pleasant and first arrive at Stevens, which was a place where they "saw nothing noticeable except three ragamuffins standing on the bridge as if brooding over some hellish plot of human destruction; stopped 10 minutes and started for Brimfield." After departing Brimfield the party set out for Stafford, in Tolland County, Connecticut, after visiting the hot baths at Stafford, or Stafford Poole, they moved on to the King's Tavern in Vernon, Connecticut, proceeding on to East Hartford, Hartford and finally Litchfield._x000d_
_x000d_
The party traveled through a good portion of Connecticut and Massachusetts on the return journey. The party stopped to view several of the factory towns, Judge Goold's Law School, Mrs. Pierce's Academy, the Unitarian Society and Mt. Holyoke are all mentioned._x000d_
_x000d_
The diary provides an interesting and personal view of travel at the time. The travelers visited and passed through many towns, stayed at a number of hotels and inns, and dined at various taverns which are all described in a humorous manner, particularly the writer's attitudes towards the hired help at the hotels, inns and taverns:_x000d_
_x000d_
"A great black fellow - the fellow prepared himself for a pull by placing the bottle between his knees; he began to tug. Mr. C. standing tiptoe for a glass of good porter. At length the cork, as it was, burst out, and with it the contents of the bottle till Mr. C after having been spattered from head to toe retreated, leaving the black fellow to stop the torrent, which he did by inserting his great black finger into the neck of the bottle."_x000d_
_x000d_
 The author also describes how the party had merriment trying to figure out if the young black servant was a boy or girl. They also bantered with an "old bouncing wench" whom he thought served him "cream of tartar" with his "beef stake" rather than "salt."_x000d_
_x000d_
 The diary contains numerous comments and descriptions of the scenery and the topography of the country traversed as well as descriptions of the towns and cities visited, with observations on the inhabitants colored by his upper class viewpoint as a member of "the gentry." His comments on local citizens are often indignant as in the following description:_x000d_
_x000d_
"...passed through the whole of East Hartford where the farms and buildings indicated a set of indolent inhabitants, living upon what their fathers had acquired, without making the least improvement, or even making good the earnings of their ancestors. This is a beautifully rich, charming? section of the country, capable of being made the garden of New England, but is suffused by its inervated occupants to go to ruins and lie in waste; the natural effect of a rich exuberant soil."_x000d_
_x000d_
Other passages indicate that the party visited the famous Charter Oak in Litchfield, then 200 years old and famous as being the hiding place of the Connecticut colony charter. While in the Litchfield area the party visited the Walcott Factories at Torrington, where "is manufactured about 100 yards of broad cloth daily, most of it of a superfine quality; 80-90 hands employed in their works, some on high, some on low wages." The party also comes across a roadside missionary donation box for the poor, where they decided not to leave any donation due to the possibility of "marauding Irishmen." _x000d_
_x000d_
The diary contains a description of a peculiar horse powered ferry that the travelers took to cross the Connecticut River on an excursion to Mt. Holyoke:_x000d_
_x000d_
 "We crossed the river in a boat propelled by two horses; one on each side continuously stepping, but stationary in relation to the boat. They both tred on a horizontal wheels as broad as the boat is wide; an pitched to a firm post, and as they draw, the wheel under them turns, on the outer edge of which are cogs passing over a shaft with cogs, [washing] across the beast, at each end of which is a wheel with buckets or paddles wading in the water pushing forward the boat."_x000d_
_x000d_
The diary's descriptions of the pastoral scenery are worth noting the following is from his description of the view from Mt. Holyoke:_x000d_
_x000d_
"On a clear day, thirty one towns can be seen from this summit; the rich meadows on the margin of the river below; the large crops of corn, almost ripe for harvest; the green and regular squares, thirsting upon the river, the scattered houses in the beautiful fields of [???] and the bows and windings of the proud Connecticut, all conspire to fill the soul with rapture, and cause it to break forth in songs of admiration, wonder and praise; and when you view these too, or it was under your feet, you will be transported to the third Heavens, while you are standing upon your Mother earth."

fields.title: Lynne Pledger Hardwick Landfill Collection
fields.desc: Lynne became engaged with waste management issues when a regional landfill tried to expand in her rural community. She honed community-organizing skills and went on to serve on the Sierra Club Zero Waste Committee, which broadened her understanding of waste issues and solutions. A writer and editor, she has helped develop PPI documents, and has made numerous presentations on EPR to citizen groups and officials in the Northeast. She is co-founder of Don’t Waste Massachusetts, an alliance of 25 environmental organizations supporting EPR and other waste reduction measures. She also works with Zero Waste groups around the Northeast. She was recently appointed to the Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection Solid Waste Advisory Committee.

fields.title: Sidney Lipshires Papers
fields.desc: Ranging from an autobiographical account that outlines his development as an activist (prepared in anticipation of a trial for conspiracy charges under the Smith Act) to drafts and notes relating to his book Giving Them Hell, the Sidney Lipshires Papers offers an overview of his role in the Communist Party and as a labor organizer. The collection also contains his testimony in a 1955 public hearing before the Special Commission to Study and Investigate Communism and Subversive Activities, photographs, and biographical materials.
